bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, December 6, 1940

div1.p: Truby thanks Hench for the clippings and program from the Lazear memorial event. He would like to have his manuscript returned soon so that he may make revisions. He reveals new information about the buildings of the yellow fever hospital and believes Lazear died in one of them.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, December 6, 1940

opener.dateline:
ALBERT E. TRUBY
145 LAUREL STREET
SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
Dec. 6 /40

div1.p:
I recieved the program of
the W. & J. dinner and the Rochester
newspaper clipping about your
address. Thank you very much
for sending them as I am of course
much interested. I have been anxious
to know how your paper was
recieved and when and where it
will be published. I noticed that
Dr. Cooke's name did not appear
on the program so I infer that
he was not present.

Will you kindly let me know when
you will be through with my mms.
While I am in no great rush to have
it back, still it must make several
more long trips to be checked up
by men who were with me in Cuba
Ac
T
I have been corresponding with
several of them recently and have
gotten quite a bit of information.
Some of it confirms my views but
one on which I felt quite confident
was shattered. I had completely forgotten
about 4 small shacks in the ff. hospital
area that had been used as a small-
pox hospital by the 1st or 2d Division Hospital.
We did not use these buildings in
1899, but while I was at Guanajay they
were used by Dr. Ames in treating some of
the Quemados y f cases. (July 1900) and he
discontinued the use of tents. While I did
not know that, I can now distinctly
remember the buildings and I believe
Dr. Lazear died in one of them. I feel
sure that I can find someone who
will know. I also think that General
Kean was treated in one of them when
he had y f-

I know that you are busy but
please give me a line. I see
you are having real winter
weather in Rochester.
